conversation:
Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me you'd be, gith.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: What's wrong? You seem different than before.
Shadowheart: No questions! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen.
Shadowheart: The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you.
Shadowheart: Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Lae'zel: The ravings of a lunatic. Strike her down.
: True
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Keep your hands away from that blade.
Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see.
Shadowheart: And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: Don't do anything rash. There has to be an explanation for this.
Shadowheart: I don't want explanations. I want sleep.
Shadowheart: The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: You're exhausted - not thinking straight. You need to rest.
: True
Shadowheart: Rest where? I can't leave. The whispers won't let me leave.
Player: Attack her.

Lae'zel: The tadpole hasn't yet scrambled all your senses. Auspicious.
Lae'zel: But the longer we wait, the more it consumes.
Lae'zel: My people possess the cure for this infection. I must find a crèche; you will join me.
Shadowheart: Careful - she obviously sees your kindness as weakness. Don't let her take advantage.
NodeContext: Speaking to the player regarding Lae'zel. Discreetly urging caution.
Player: Join me, then. But I'll be watching you closely.
Lae'zel: Very well. But heed my words.

Narrator: *Your skull briefly aches, and you are her. You feel the woman's anger at the dragon-rider she'd confronted.*
Narrator: *You also feel answers. She knows more about your condition.*
Lae'zel: You left me for dead. I've killed my own cousins for considerably less.
: True
Narrator: *You note the look in her eye, the slight tilt of her head. She is sizing you up.*
Lae'zel: Yet even a feared kith'rak could not break your spirit. Yes - you may be of considerable use.
Lae'zel: I know of a cure. Lend me your skills, and I will take you to it.
Shadowheart: Lies. Just get rid of her.
Player: The artefact suddenly seems to weigh heavily on you. Quickly turn to other matters.

Lae'zel: This means a crèche is near.
Player: I honour our alliance, kin. Let us seek a crèche.
Lae'zel: You have made an ally from Crèche K'liir - few know such fortune. Call me Lae'zel.

Shadowheart: This again? You're persistent, I'll give you that.
Shadowheart: It's nothing. Really.
Player: We have to be honest with each other. What is it you're keeping from me?
: True
Shadowheart: You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had...
Shadowheart: I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers.
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Shadowheart: Don't make a fuss, Selûnite - we may be at odds, but I have more important concerns than you right now.
Shadowheart: Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Player: I'll decide whether to make a fuss or not. Hard to trust someone who's holding out on me.
Shadowheart: Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield.
Shadowheart: I even keep secrets from myself - I had my memories suppressed, so that nothing I knew could be used against the Dark Lady. Once I prove myself, my memories will be restored.
Shadowheart: I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit.
Shadowheart: Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: Let's see how open-minded I can be then: tell me more.
Player: Now that the truth's out, tell me more.
Shadowheart: All right. As I said, Shar is my patron, my mistress. Goddess of darkness and loss.
Shadowheart: I assume you've heard of her?
Player: Remind me.
Shadowheart: My Lady Shar is the Nightsinger. The patron of darkness and loss.
Player: Fascinating. Please, continue.
Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected.
Shadowheart: But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act.
Shadowheart: Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts.
Shadowheart: We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: How exactly do Shar worshippers turn people to their goddess?
Shadowheart: We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. The lives they cling to.
Shadowheart: We destroy false idols, topple corrupt organisations, fight heretics wherever they're found.
Shadowheart: There's often suffering - death even. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.
Player: It sounds evil.

Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected.
Shadowheart: But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act.
Shadowheart: Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts.
Shadowheart: We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: Sounds... daunting. I don't think it's for me.
Shadowheart: Give it time - and thought.
Shadowheart: We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. The lives they cling to.
Shadowheart: We destroy false idols, topple corrupt organisations, fight heretics wherever they're found.
Shadowheart: There's often suffering - death even. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.
Player: It sounds evil.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ulma pauses for a moment, staring at the fire in contemplation before she turns and walks over to the player.
Ulma: So, the impossible spawn walks among us in the blazing sun. We have been looking for you.
Astarion: And here I am. What do you want?
Ulma: The last time you came to our camp, you stole our children. Our future.
Gandrel: When I was hunting you, I was to bring you back here. To interrogate you, discover how to save our children, and then destroy you.
Ulma: But things have changed. You have changed.
Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: Yes, it's true.
Ulma: Then maybe you have a chance to redeem yourself.
Ulma: We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended.
Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.
Ulma: He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: You think you can guilt me into doing what you're too weak to?
Ulma: We offer you a chance, perhaps your final chance, to heal just some of the pain you have caused.
Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Forget it, I'm not sacrificing myself for your cause.

Narrator: *An ornate mace hovers before you, suspended in a shaft of brilliant light.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*
: True

Gale: Are you quite sure that's wise?
Lae'zel: Step away. And banish this mace from your mind.
Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.*
Narrator: *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.*
Narrator: *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Take the mace anyway - what's the worst that could happen?

Zarys: You're the one who recruited me, Rugan.
NodeContext: She's overseeing the torture of an agent of hers - one who originally recruited her to the organisation. Tone is chiding and also vaguely disgusted - he should have known better.
Zarys: You're the one who taught me rule number one, remember?
NodeContext: As if reflecting on 'good old days', but with a harder edge
Rugan: Bwaah.
Zarys: No. Olly didn't remember either, did you Olly?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Close-up of Olly lying on the floor - already tortured to death,
NodeContext: Olly is bound to a chair on the floor, tortued to death
NodeContext: Olly is bound to a chair on the floor, tortued to death
Zarys: You're dead the moment you steal from the Zhentarim.
Zarys: No matter who you are.
: True
Narrator: *You recall an old Zhentarim proverb coined by their founder.*
: False
Player: I'm going to walk out of here alive. Play it right, and so will you.
: True

NodeContext: Genuine laughter - you're threatening her gang despite the odds being heavily stacked against you. She's won over by it.
Zarys: Tell you what: you've already taken Rugan's cargo, so finish the job and I'll let you live. Deliver it to Baldur's Gate.
Zarys: Oh, and kill him.
Player: I won't do that.

Shadow-Whiskers: Another? Good.
Player: That cage looks comfy.
Shadow-Whiskers: Mock me. Tease me. You will be the first.
Player: Tell me what you're up to or I set this cage on fire.
: True
Shadow-Whiskers: Look. See. The crowd - they laugh. They shine with innocence. But it is a lie.
Shadow-Whiskers: Every one of you is vicious. Cruel. You kill my mate. Steal my cubs.

Shadow-Whiskers: I roar. Break my cage - and then you die. You all die.
Player: Sure thing, pussycat. Later.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith gains her composure and motions everyone to rise. Everyone present rises.

Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Your kind's stoic endurance will be a boon to our cause.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: Can't you kill them yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Gish Far'aag: Sentries, to arms! Istik. State your purpose. Quickly.
Lae'zel: Stand down, gish. Is it not Vlaakith's command to welcome her faithful?
Gish Far'aag: I expected no visitors, faithful or otherwise. Why have you come?
Player: Allow Lae'zel to answer.
Lae'zel: We seek the zaith'isk. Show me the way.
Gish Far'aag: You are infected?
Player: I found the weapon you seek. Want to explain to Voss why you killed me?
Gish Far'aag: You've talked to one of our queen's silver knights, and hold the lost weapon? Prove it, istik.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs within your pocket - suddenly within your reach, but reluctant to be known to the githyanki.*
Player: Produce the artefact as evidence.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?
Player: I've come to free you - I already dealt with some of the Banites.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Blek'ith! Why?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.
Player: It's worth the risk - worst case scenario, you die fighting.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: If it were only our lives on the line, we'd have rebelled long ago.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: It's selfish to value your families more than an entire city.

Lyrthindor: But you ruined it. Trespassed. Spoiled our - my - secret. Now you'll rot in the dark.
Player: I'm glad I did it. The world's better off without Shar worshippers skulking about.

Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: Yes, it's true.
Ulma: Then maybe you have a chance to redeem yourself.
Ulma: We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended.
Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.
Ulma: He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: And if I decline to help?
Ulma: Then we can all see what you really are. At best, a coward. At worst, a monster.
Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Forget it, I'm not sacrificing myself for your cause.

Gish Far'aag: Sentries, to arms! Istik. State your purpose. Quickly.
Lae'zel: Stand down, gish. Is it not Vlaakith's command to welcome her faithful?
Gish Far'aag: I expected no visitors, faithful or otherwise. Why have you come?
Player: I have the weapon Voss was looking for, that your crèche wanted found.
GROUP_Daisy: What are you doing?!
Gish Far'aag: You've talked to one of our queen's silver knights, and hold the lost weapon? Prove it, istik.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs within your pocket - suddenly within your reach, but reluctant to be known to the githyanki.*
Player: I will report to your kith'rak as protocol dictates. Do not forget yourself.
: True
Gish Far'aag: Forgive me, ra'stil. Our nerves are somewhat heightened with the Inquisition's presence.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [opening, face-to-face]

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Wyll: One horn. The stink of Avernus. Advocatus diaboli.
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Wyll: Karlach. The archdevil Zariel's gladiator, come to burn the Sword Coast to ash.
Player: You've got it all wrong, Wyll. Karlach's not about to hurt anyone.
Karlach: Well - not counting the fuckers that need a good hurting.
Wyll: Shut it, devil - I know your kind. A heart darker than a shadow's nightmares. You'd cut a child's throat just to taste the blood.
Karlach: A devil? I didn't take the Blade for a fool. I'm - ngh!
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.
Narrator: *Another vision. Karlach's blade raised, slicing through devils - Zariel's servants - as her eyes dart around, seeking escape.*
Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Wyll: By Balduran's helm, I - no. I will not be tricked!
Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.
Player: Stand down. You saw what I saw - Karlach is not a danger.
: True
Narrator: *Wyll catches his breath, and his lips straighten. Sheer dread twists his face.*
Wyll: No. Devils can not be trusted!
Player: You're right. Let's cut her down before she causes any trouble.

Sebastian: Please, help us.
Sebastian: He won't ever let you die.
: True

Player: How did this happen to you?
Sebastian: Then it gets so dark. I woke up here. Like this.
: True
Narrator: *Under the grime, you can see how pale he is. You can see the hunger in his eyes - in all of their eyes. Each one is an emaciated, starving vampire spawn.*
Narrator: *More than that, you can see that each prisoner is marked with a scar - the same as one of the runes from Astarion's back.*

Sebastian: You can't. It's not possible.
Player: Just tell me where to find him. I'll do the rest.
Sebastian: The grand chamber, just ahead...
Sebastian: But even if you can kill him - what then? What happens to us?
Player: I'll set you free - what else?

Akabi: BEHOLD - AKABI'S WHEEL OF WONDERS.
Akabi: SPIN TO WIN PRIZES BEYOND YOUR TINY IMAGINATION, AND MAKE YOUR MISERABLE LIFE MORE BEARABLE. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Akabi: LET US SEE IF YOU HAVE LUCK'S FAVOUR.

Akabi: You dare speak to me as if we were equals? You are a scrap of food in my teeth. The dirt beneath my fingernails. You are nothing.

Barcus Wroot: You - this was not the deal! You were meant to stop this madness - not... not... enmadden it!
Player: I'm sorry - there was no other way.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.
The Warden: Is that so? If you are above the General's chief advisor, you must be most impressive.

Player: I'm actually Balthazar's closest confidante.
: True
The Warden: I didn't know he had such... refined taste.
The Warden: I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.

Nightwarden Minthara: I expected to be greeted as a hero - but the wretches imprisoned me, and tried to tear my mind apart.

Sa'varsh Kethk: Stay out of this, istik. They need to learn what happens when they fail to follow orders.
NodeContext: Dismissive of player's interruption, with a malicious smile

Sa'varsh Kethk: Silence! It seems your childish prattling is attracting an audience.
NodeContext: Teacher finally acnowledges the player
Sa'varsh Kethk: You fight again. This time, daggers only. And to the death as instructed.
Sa'varsh Kethk: Who wants to challenge this snivelling is'tark?
Player: I'd bring him to the edge of death. Leave him asking why he deserves to live.
Player: Offer to fight the boy yourself.
Sa'varsh Kethk: An interesting proposition.

Lae'zel: Lesser? A Crèche K'liir hatchling would not have dared defy an elder.
Sa'varsh Kethk: One bad egg does not reflect the true power of Crèche Y'llek.
Sa'varsh Kethk: Take a dagger, stranger. This exercise requires nothing more than a blade, and a backbone.

Sa'varsh Kethk: What are you waiting for? Begin!

Gish Far'aag: Sentries, to arms! Istik. State your purpose. Quickly.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel steps forward, confident.
Lae'zel: Supreme Kith'rak. Has Vlaakith sent you to slay me with your own blade?
Kith'rak Voss: I've not come to kill you, Lae'zel. I've come to aid you.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't trust him.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] Voss kneels and lays his sword on the ground in the githyanki sign of submission.
Kith'rak Voss: Ska'kek kir Gith shabell'eth. My blade rests. Mother Gith compels you to listen.
Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?
Kith'rak Voss: I knew you would fight - and I knew you would win. I needed to ensure Vlaakith's trust. This was the only way.
Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.
Kith'rak Voss: Within it lies the seed of Vlaakith's demise. And I intend to help you bring it to fruition.
Lae'zel: Vlaakith's demise? Shka'keth. I should run you through for suggesting it.
Player: You must be either a fool or a hero to work against your own queen.
Kith'rak Voss: A fool stumbles without cause. A hero serves a cause without question.
Kith'rak Voss: I am neither. 'Clear of heart, clear of mind, and bound by no master.' Now - you must listen.
Kith'rak Voss: The Prism's tenant can put an end to Vlaakith's tyranny. They must be let loose.
Kith'rak Voss: I've sought their freedom for aeons. When the Prism went missing, I feared the worst.
Kith'rak Voss: Instead, you've granted the opportunity I've so long awaited.
Kith'rak Voss: All that remains is the key that unchains them - and I've found someone who I believe can provide it.
Kith'rak Voss: Bring the Prism to Baldur's Gate. I'll be waiting in a taproom called Sharess' Caress. That is where we decide the fate of my people.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.
NodeContext: Not nearly as aggressive as usual. She believes him but is keeping up appearances.
Lae'zel: I... I will hear no more of it.
NodeContext: Rising alittle in anger but questioning. She is ready to be convinced. But she has to keep up appearances.
Player: Kill him. This is your chance to earn Vlaakith's redemption.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Who exactly are you?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel grimaces in anger, but remains silent
Vlaakith: Who... am... I?
Vlaakith: I am Vlaakith. Undying Queen of the noble githyanki. God Regent of the Six Arms of Tu'narath.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith gains her composure and motions everyone to rise. Everyone present rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Child of Gith. You carry what is mine. Do I call you loyal servant - or thief?
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Neither. It is mine by rights.
Vlaakith: No. It is not 'yours'. To own something is to know it.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: Can't you kill them yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?
Player: I've come to free you - I already dealt with some of the Banites.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Blek'ith! Why?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: If everyone who wears a collar is helping to build the Steel Watch, killing you all may be a good thing.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: A grim solution, but one that I may agree with if your understanding of the situation were correct.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Unfortunately, we are not the only ones threatened by the collars, or we would have laid down our tools, and rebelled against our oppressors already.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: It's selfish to value your families more than an entire city.

Volo: I was just settling in and reviewing my latest findings. Mind flayers, cultists, and of course, your esteemed company!
Player: Has your research turned up anything that might help with this parasite problem?
Volo: My research turned up a rather brilliant technique that seems quite actionable.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Volo pulls out a needle
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye

Player: Endure the discomfort. Let him carry on.

Player: Clench your fists.

Narrator: *The needle see-saws back and forth, plucking the nerve like a harp string.*

Ghustil Stornugoss: Vertical incision from pineal eye to end of notochord.

Ghustil Stornugoss: Intestinal colouration consistent with samples 231 to 259.

She turns at the end of her question to see the player's response

True Soul Gut: Whole camp'll be branded soon. An' you should be, too.
True Soul Gut: You ready? Brace yourself - this'll sting.

Narrator: *An ornate mace hovers before you, suspended in a shaft of brilliant light.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*
: True
Narrator: *This mace must be the legendary Blood of Lathander - the amber is said to contain the blood of the Morninglord himself.*

Lae'zel: Stay your hand! The consequences may be more than we are ready to bear.

Ulma: Rech té i hathran roost.

Ulma: But things have changed. You have changed.
Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?

Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.

Ulma: We offer you a chance, perhaps your final chance, to heal just some of the pain you have caused.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [opening, face-to-face]

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Wyll: One horn. The stink of Avernus. Advocatus diaboli.
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Wyll: Karlach. The archdevil Zariel's gladiator, come to burn the Sword Coast to ash.
Player: You've got it all wrong, Wyll. Karlach's not about to hurt anyone.
Karlach: Well - not counting the fuckers that need a good hurting.
Wyll: Shut it, devil - I know your kind. A heart darker than a shadow's nightmares. You'd cut a child's throat just to taste the blood.
Karlach: A devil? I didn't take the Blade for a fool. I'm - ngh!
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.
Narrator: *Another vision. Karlach's blade raised, slicing through devils - Zariel's servants - as her eyes dart around, seeking escape.*
Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Wyll: By Balduran's helm, I - no. I will not be tricked!
Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.
Player: Stand down. You saw what I saw - Karlach is not a danger.
: False
Wyll: No. Devils can not be trusted!
Player: It's you I don't trust, Wyll. You wanted a fight? You've got it.
Karlach: How about we all take a nice deep breath and calm the fuck down. Just cause I want to live doesn't mean I want him dead.
Player: But I do. The Blade of Frontiers will be only a memory come tomorrow.

Player: Has your research turned up anything that might help with this parasite problem?
Volo: My research turned up a rather brilliant technique that seems quite actionable.

~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye

Player: Clench your fists.

Narrator: *The needle see-saws back and forth, plucking the nerve like a harp string.*

Shadowheart: What do you know about me? You spoke of my past, being chased by wolves - I told no one about that...
Shadowheart: ...Almost no one. But I certainly didn't share that with you.
Nightsong: There is nothing I can tell you that you do not already know yourself. They trained you well, trained you hard. Chiselled away any part of you that did not fit their plan. They made you forget.
Shadowheart: I chose to do that. For the mission. To protect Shar's -
Nightsong: - secrets. Yes, yes. That is an old song, girl. Your goddess cares more for her precious secrets than she does her devotees.
Shadowheart: Get to the point.
Nightsong: When you freed me, you severed a bond between me and that dog, Thorm. A bond of pain - his, inflicted on me.
Nightsong: When I laid eyes on you, I sensed a similar bond. You, tethered to two others, someplace distant. Let me help you remember.
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's mind tug at the edges of your own. You know this sensation. She wants you to see whatever is about to be revealed.*
Player: Open your mind to that sensation.
Narrator: *Your mind joins with Shadowheart's. Something pulls at you both, bringing you elsewhere...*
: True
Narrator: *...It seems that one child never came back. She was taken.*
Shadowheart: What... who was that man?
Nightsong: You already know. Did you not see yourself in him? Do you not recognise your own blood?
Shadowheart: My father? That was him?
Nightsong: That is him. He lives still, and your mother too.
Shadowheart: No, it can't be. I'm an orphan.
Nightsong: And who told you that? Your adoptive family? You are not to blame. You were young, impressionable. They took you because they wanted to break and remake you.
Nightsong: But you are a child no longer. You are a woman. One who knows what must be done.
Shadowheart: My parents. I need to save them.
Player: We've got other concerns.
Nightsong: There are always other concerns. Let Shadowheart at least be forewarned.

Player: I'm here to spill your guts across the floor.

Shadow-Whiskers: Another? Good.
Player: That cage looks comfy.
Shadow-Whiskers: Mock me. Tease me. You will be the first.
Player: Tell me what you're up to or I set this cage on fire.
: True
Shadow-Whiskers: Look. See. The crowd - they laugh. They shine with innocence. But it is a lie.
Shadow-Whiskers: Every one of you is vicious. Cruel. You kill my mate. Steal my cubs.
Halsin: Poor creature - locked in a cage, denied her true nature. Civilisation would call her a monstrosity, yet it treats her like this...?
Shadow-Whiskers: I roar. Break my cage - and then you die. You all die.
Player: Murder whoever you want. I'll be long gone.

Demir: Bloody hells, she just disappeared. Ain't seen nothing like that before.
Johl: She could shoot fireworks out of her backside for all I care; the hag has Rina.
Player: Will someone please tell me what's going on?
Demir: It's our sister - Mayrina. She is... well, she was in a bad way after her husband died.
Johl: Started saying weird things, like how she was gonna bring him back.
Demir: Next thing, she's gone looking for the hag. Of all the stupid things to do.
Demir: We haven't seen her since, and no good ever came from dealing with a hag.
Johl: None of this matters, all right? We need to get her back. And fast.
Player: Let me - I'll bring Mayrina home.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?
Player: I've come to free you - I already dealt with some of the Banites.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Blek'ith! Why?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.
Player: Rise up in unison - they can't stop you all.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Even if we did somehow unshackle our collars simultaneously, and overthrow our oppressors, there would be consequences.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: It's selfish to value your families more than an entire city.

Sebastian: Please, help us.
Sebastian: He won't ever let you die.
: True
Narrator: *Under the grime, you can see how pale he is. You can see the hunger in his eyes - in all of their eyes. Each one is an emaciated, starving vampire spawn.*
Narrator: *More than that, you can see that each prisoner is marked with a scar - the same as one of the runes from Astarion's back.*
Player: I'm going to help you. I'm going to kill Cazador.
Sebastian: You can't. It's not possible.
Player: Just tell me where to find him. I'll do the rest.
Sebastian: The grand chamber, just ahead...
Sebastian: But even if you can kill him - what then? What happens to us?
Player: I'll set you free - what else?

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Who exactly are you?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel grimaces in anger, but remains silent
Vlaakith: Who... am... I?
Vlaakith: I am Vlaakith. Undying Queen of the noble githyanki. God Regent of the Six Arms of Tu'narath.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith gains her composure and motions everyone to rise. Everyone present rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Your kind's heritage is long and storied. It is an honour to be served by one so noble.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Gish Far'aag: Sentries, to arms! Istik. State your purpose. Quickly.
Lae'zel: Stand down, gish. Is it not Vlaakith's command to welcome her faithful?
Gish Far'aag: I expected no visitors, faithful or otherwise. Why have you come?
Player: I was infected by an illithid, and was told to seek a githyanki crèche.
Gish Far'aag: You are infected?
Player: I found the weapon you seek. Want to explain to Voss why you killed me?
Gish Far'aag: You've talked to one of our queen's silver knights, and hold the lost weapon? Prove it, istik.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs within your pocket - suddenly within your reach, but reluctant to be known to the githyanki.*
Player: Produce the artefact as evidence.

Narrator: *An ornate mace hovers before you, suspended in a shaft of brilliant light.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*
: True
Narrator: *This mace must be the legendary Blood of Lathander - the amber is said to contain the blood of the Morninglord himself.*

Gale: Are you quite sure that's wise?

Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.*
Narrator: *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.*
Narrator: *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Claim the mace and delight in its danger.

Sa'varsh Kethk: What are you waiting for? Begin!
Youth Varrl: I - I refuse. There has to be a better way -
Sa'varsh Kethk: G'lyck. Kill him, and put us all out of our misery.

Manip Bakshi: What in the Nine bloody Hells is going on? Reynash?
Manip Bakshi: You've got one breath to explain why you're in here, or you're going straight to the cells.
Player: I saw one of your officers acting suspiciously near that chest.

Manip Bakshi: That's impossible. Reynash was on duty the whole -
Manip Bakshi: That sneaky little git. It was him all along?
Player: How embarrassing. Isn't it your job to catch criminals?
Manip Bakshi: We're preparing for an invasion. You think we have time to go after petty thieves?
Manip Bakshi: Now unless you want me pinning this on you - get out!
Player: Let him arrest you.

Karlach: Just when I was getting used to the sky again...
Gale: Fear not, Karlach. Sun, moon and stars will still be there waiting for us.
Karlach: Meanwhile, this place is pretty spectacular, isn't it?
Gale: No book or painting could ever do its strange beauty justice. But perhaps our stories might, when we return to the surface.

Lae'zel: Honoured kith'rak. May Vlaakith show us truth.

Kith'rak Therezzyn: It is small. Angular. Metal. Adorned with tir'su script. Stolen by 'True Soul' heretics.

Player: I don't know anything about it.
: False
Kith'rak Therezzyn: And yet your face betrays you. You found it, didn't you?
Kith'rak Therezzyn: Ch'mar zal'a Vlaakith! Give it to me.

Goblin Booyahg: Let the Absolute hear your prayers. Let the blood of Her enemies flow over you!
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Step up to the shrine, touching your fingers to your heart and your head.

NodeContext: As if reflecting on 'good old days', but with a harder edge

Zarys: Oh, and kill him.

Nightwarden Minthara: The voice... silenced. And my abusers, dead.
Nightwarden Minthara: I didn't think anyone would come for me.

Nightwarden Minthara: Erasing my thoughts, and my will. Even I could not have endured for much longer.

GROUP_Emperors: Did you not hear me? I said TURN BACK.
GROUP_Emperors: The Morphic Pool is beneath the city. That is where we must go. Do not waste your time here - turn back!
Player: I don't care - let's go through.

Shadowheart: What do you know about me? You spoke of my past, being chased by wolves - I told no one about that...
Shadowheart: ...Almost no one. But I certainly didn't share that with you.
Nightsong: There is nothing I can tell you that you do not already know yourself. They trained you well, trained you hard. Chiselled away any part of you that did not fit their plan. They made you forget.
Shadowheart: I chose to do that. For the mission. To protect Shar's -
Nightsong: - secrets. Yes, yes. That is an old song, girl. Your goddess cares more for her precious secrets than she does her devotees.
Shadowheart: Get to the point.
Nightsong: When you freed me, you severed a bond between me and that dog, Thorm. A bond of pain - his, inflicted on me.
Nightsong: When I laid eyes on you, I sensed a similar bond. You, tethered to two others, someplace distant. Let me help you remember.
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's mind tug at the edges of your own. You know this sensation. She wants you to see whatever is about to be revealed.*
Player: Open your mind to that sensation.
Narrator: *Your mind joins with Shadowheart's. Something pulls at you both, bringing you elsewhere...*
Narrator: *Something sparks in your memory. Teachings about Selûnite rites of passage, about how they would abandon their children out in the wilds and force them to find their way home...*
Narrator: *...It seems that one child never came back. She was taken.*
Shadowheart: What... who was that man?
Nightsong: You already know. Did you not see yourself in him? Do you not recognise your own blood?
Shadowheart: My father? That was him?
Nightsong: That is him. He lives still, and your mother too.
Shadowheart: No, it can't be. I'm an orphan.
Nightsong: And who told you that? Your adoptive family? You are not to blame. You were young, impressionable. They took you because they wanted to break and remake you.
Nightsong: But you are a child no longer. You are a woman. One who knows what must be done.
Shadowheart: My parents. I need to save them.
Player: We've got other concerns.
Nightsong: There are always other concerns. Let Shadowheart at least be forewarned.

Narrator: *You recognise the funeral rites of the Gur people - the same monster hunters you met in the hag's swamp. Their leader is burning the possessions of those who have fallen.*
Ulma: Im orak ne tay. Krasin ne trah!

Ulma: So, the impossible spawn walks among us in the blazing sun. We have been looking for you.
Astarion: And here I am. What do you want?
Ulma: The last time you came to our camp, you stole our children. Our future.
Gandrel: When I was hunting you, I was to bring you back here. To interrogate you, discover how to save our children, and then destroy you.
Ulma: But things have changed. You have changed.
Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: Somewhat. It's... complicated.
Ulma: Then I shall make things simple. You stole our little ones from us - can you steal them back from your master?
Ulma: We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended.
Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.
Ulma: He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: You think you can guilt me into doing what you're too weak to?
Ulma: We offer you a chance, perhaps your final chance, to heal just some of the pain you have caused.
Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Forget it, I'm not sacrificing myself for your cause.

Ulma: Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: Somewhat. It's... complicated.
Ulma: Then I shall make things simple. You stole our little ones from us - can you steal them back from your master?
Ulma: We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended.
Ulma: But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining.
Ulma: He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: And if I decline to help?
Ulma: Then we can all see what you really are. At best, a coward. At worst, a monster.
Ulma: So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Forget it, I'm not sacrificing myself for your cause.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: What's going on here?
He Who Was: You walk in the darkness, unafraid? How curious.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
: True
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Depends. Who murdered this woman?
He Who Was: She is not the victim. Nay, she is the perpetrator.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: Her soul has departed for the Fugue Plane, to be judged or lost forever. What more could she pay?
He Who Was: The Fugue Plane is no obstacle to one such as I.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Why would you do that?
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Big Huido: Mate, what part of 'Guild business' isn't getting through that stone-skull of yours?
Big Huido: Whoa, whoa, mate - this is the last place you need to be. Clear off, yeah?
Player: Why can't I be here?
Big Huido: Two words - Guild business. Only an idiot gets between them and their shipments.
Player: Give me that shipment or die. Choose.

Big Huido: Easy, mate. We're humble smugglers, all right? So just - just take whatever you want.
Player: Empty your pockets, too. Now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.

The Warden: The Absolute thanks you for this generous donation, True Soul. You can go now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel steps forward, confident.
Lae'zel: Supreme Kith'rak. Has Vlaakith sent you to slay me with your own blade?
Kith'rak Voss: I've not come to kill you, Lae'zel. I've come to aid you.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't trust him.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] Voss kneels and lays his sword on the ground in the githyanki sign of submission.
Kith'rak Voss: Ska'kek kir Gith shabell'eth. My blade rests. Mother Gith compels you to listen.
Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?
Kith'rak Voss: I knew you would fight - and I knew you would win. I needed to ensure Vlaakith's trust. This was the only way.
Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.
Kith'rak Voss: Within it lies the seed of Vlaakith's demise. And I intend to help you bring it to fruition.
Lae'zel: Vlaakith's demise? Shka'keth. I should run you through for suggesting it.
Player: Vlaakith is my queen. Why would I want to end her?
Kith'rak Voss: Because her throne rests on lies, more than a hundred gish scholars could count in a lifetime. I will share but two.
Lae'zel: No. I don't believe it.
Kith'rak Voss: Your doubt does not make it any less true, child.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.
NodeContext: Not nearly as aggressive as usual. She believes him but is keeping up appearances.
Lae'zel: I... I will hear no more of it.
NodeContext: Rising alittle in anger but questioning. She is ready to be convinced. But she has to keep up appearances.
Player: Vlaakith's led you astray. I believe him, and so should you.

Cora Highberry: No - the grocer's just been, as has the chandler. Then there's your tailor - he's due soon to get the children outfitted for the festival...
Roger Highberry: And of course, the Wine Festival itself is but a few days away - Cora, we do forget ourselves! We've not even asked this fine young stranger's name.
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].  And you are?
Cora Highberry: I am Cora Highberry, and this is my husband, Roger. Delighted to meet you.
Roger Highberry: More than delighted! A little extra company's always welcome as we enter our twilight years - yet another reason we're putting on the wine festival!
Player: I bet that'll draw quite the crowd in a city like this.
Cora Highberry: We hope so, it's going to be right on our doorstep!
Roger Highberry: The festival was put together to raise funds for the children, you see. Times are a touch tough at the moment.
Player: Which children are you raising money for?
Roger Highberry: Young Molly and Timothy, who we've recently taken charge of. Their parents... Well. War leaves the nastiest scars.
Player: Perhaps a small donation would help salve those scars? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Ketheric Thorm: YOU! What have you done?! What have you done to me?!

Ketheric jerkily turns toward the player with hatred in his eyes.
InternalNodeContext: INTRO: Before initial fight
Ketheric Thorm: YOU! What have you done?! What have you done to me?!

Tremors shake the tower now and then, evidence of Nightsong's assault.
Ketheric jerkily turns toward the player with hatred in his eyes.
InternalNodeContext: INTRO: Before initial fight
Ketheric Thorm: You desecrate my halls. Kill my faithful. What heresy twists inside you?!
Player: Surrender now, and I'll consider letting you live.
: True
Ketheric Thorm: You've come this far. You've stripped your enemy of his advantage. Why would you show mercy now?
Player: I'm not like you, Ketheric. My only interest is what is right.
: True
Ketheric Thorm: Who decides what is right? The gods did not care for right and wrong when they dismantled my life piece by piece.
Ketheric Thorm: And when I tried to buy it back, it cost me everything - everything.
Ketheric Thorm: We are copper pieces in their belts. Tokens to be traded for scraps.
Ketheric Thorm: You have beaten me, True Soul. But the gods beat me first.
Ketheric Thorm: And now... perhaps it is over.
Player: I can help you, Ketheric - if you let me.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.
The Warden: Is that so? If you are above the General's chief advisor, you must be most impressive.
: True
Narrator: *Her smirk hides her intent - she's toying with you.*
Player: I'm not here to play games - I need to speak to the prisoners. Now.
The Warden: That tone might work on swaddled babes and puppies, but I am neither, True Soul.
The Warden: I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.
Player: Fine.  ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
The Warden: Pockets running a little empty, are they?
The Warden: Disciple Balthazar's orders still stand - none may speak to the prisoners. You can go now.
The Warden: The Absolute thanks you for this generous donation, True Soul. You can go now.
Player: I should have seen that coming.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [opening, face-to-face]

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Wyll: One horn. The stink of Avernus. Advocatus diaboli.
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Wyll: Karlach. The archdevil Zariel's gladiator, come to burn the Sword Coast to ash.
Player: You've got it all wrong, Wyll. Karlach's not about to hurt anyone.
Karlach: Well - not counting the fuckers that need a good hurting.
Wyll: Shut it, devil - I know your kind. A heart darker than a shadow's nightmares. You'd cut a child's throat just to taste the blood.
Karlach: A devil? I didn't take the Blade for a fool. I'm - ngh!
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.
Narrator: *Another vision. Karlach's blade raised, slicing through devils - Zariel's servants - as her eyes dart around, seeking escape.*
Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Wyll: By Balduran's helm, I - no. I will not be tricked!
Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.
Player: Stand down. You saw what I saw - Karlach is not a danger.
: False
Wyll: No. Devils can not be trusted!
Player: It's you I don't trust, Wyll. You wanted a fight? You've got it.
Karlach: How about we all take a nice deep breath and calm the fuck down. Just cause I want to live doesn't mean I want him dead.
Player: Fine, but he needs to stand down. We saw the truth for ourselves.
Karlach: Would you listen to sense? This doesn't have to end badly - for either of us.
Karlach: You know monsters better than anyone. Can't you look in my eyes and see I'm not a devil?
Wyll: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Wyll: Shit. Shit.
Wyll: You really are no devil, are you? I've... I've been deceived.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HagSurvivors_HagSpy: You removed my hex? Ah, that's annoying.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HagSurvivors_HagSpy: I wanted to play a little longer, Auntie likes her toys broken. She's not going to be happy I had to get my hands dirty.
Player: Ready yourself to attack.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HagSurvivors_HagSpy: How cute - I see why Auntie has her eye on you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HagSurvivors_HagSpy: I know you wish to hurt Auntie Ethel. I know the book is here. I will die before I let you touch a hair on her head.
Player: And I know ten ways to kill you before you can blink. We doing this or not?

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Interesting. My ardents reported that an istik survived the crashed ghaik slave-vessel.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.
Player: I have the weapon - I would say that puts me in a strong position to bargain with you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Is that so? Well, then - humour me. What would you ask of an Inquisitor?
NodeContext: Bemused, snarky
Player: I could use an ally against the illithids. As could you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: If you desire to see the might of my people, you will not be disappointed.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Our swords are ready to cleave ghaik flesh in their legions. With or without your interference.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Give me the weapon. Now.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: You can't trust him, Lae'zel. Follow my lead. I will choose the right path.
: True
Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth.

Bex: Please, I just want to be alone.
Player: I remember you - Bex, right? Where's your man?
Bex: Gone.
Bex: Cultists... It was so dark I didn't realise until the children started screaming.
Bex: They rounded us up... cut us up... Said they were taking whoever could still walk to Moonrise Towers.
Bex: I managed to get away, but my love Danis... Mar zindur vroshan.
Player: How did you manage to get away?
Bex: I've always been good at running - unlike Danis.
Bex: I didn't realise one day our lives would depend on it.
Bex: I just wish I could have said goodbye.
Player: Is there anything I can do to help?
Bex: Not unless you can bring him back.
Bex: Can you?
Bex: I wish I hadn't let go of him.
Player: From what I've heard, they've probably killed and eaten him. In that order, if he's lucky.

Balthazar: How often do I have to repeat myself? No disturbances.
NodeContext: Irate, distracted
Balthazar: Wait - you're no underling of mine. Far too intact for my tastes. That means you're a trespasser.
Balthazar: General Thorm didn't inform me you were coming, which means you're trespassing.
Player: Stare vacantly, pretending to be a thrall.
: True
Balthazar: Ah, my mistake. I should have known by your gormless demeanour. You've had your mind decluttered and have been put to work.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel steps forward, confident.
Lae'zel: Supreme Kith'rak. Has Vlaakith sent you to slay me with your own blade?
Kith'rak Voss: I've not come to kill you, Lae'zel. I've come to aid you.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't trust him.

Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?
Kith'rak Voss: I knew you would fight - and I knew you would win. I needed to ensure Vlaakith's trust. This was the only way.
Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.

Kith'rak Voss: It is not.
Kith'rak Voss: I've heard word from Crèche Y'llek. You are infected - yet the one in the Prism has chosen you, protects you with their power.
Kith'rak Voss: The Prism's tenant alone has the power to end Vlaakith's tyranny.
Kith'rak Voss: I've sought their freedom for aeons. When the Prism went missing, I feared the worst.
Kith'rak Voss: Instead, you've granted the opportunity I've so long awaited.
Kith'rak Voss: All that remains is the key that unchains them - and I've found someone who I believe can provide it.
Kith'rak Voss: Bring the Prism to Baldur's Gate. I'll be waiting in a taproom called Sharess' Caress. That is where we decide the fate of my people.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.
NodeContext: Not nearly as aggressive as usual. She believes him but is keeping up appearances.
Lae'zel: I... I will hear no more of it.
NodeContext: Rising alittle in anger but questioning. She is ready to be convinced. But she has to keep up appearances.
Player: Vlaakith's led you astray. I believe him, and so should you.

Narrator: *The device is strange, made of taut flesh and pockmarked metal. It waits for something.*
Lae'zel: The zaith'isk. Vlaakith's purity, distilled. My duty. My right.
Player: Go ahead, Lae'zel. You've earned it.
Lae'zel: Praise Vlaakith, let it be done.
Ghustil Stornugoss: Sit, child. Let the zaith'isk end your suffering.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

: False

Lae'zel: Lash'a'kla! Lash'a'kla! Lash'a'kla!

Big Huido: Two words - Guild business. Only an idiot gets between them and their shipments.

Player: No. Our only course is to deny it. This power is just another symptom of disease. And every use will sicken us further.
Player: If this power comes from these parasites, it can't be trusted. However useful it might be.

-obey-  --yield---

GROUP_Emperors: The Morphic Pool is beneath the city. That is where we must go. Do not waste your time here - turn back!

Wulbren Bongle: Your friend is some smooth talker to shut a guard down like that. What do you lot want with me, exactly?

Booyahg Piddle: Hard enough readin' this without you stinkin' up the place.
Player: Where did you find that?
Booyahg Piddle: Belonged to some bloke that showed up here askin' questions. Bold as a bugbear, he woz!
Booyahg Piddle: Said he's writin' a book about the Absolute. Lads didn't like that - said he was a spy or some such...
Booyahg Piddle: ... think they've locked 'im in the cells already.
Booyahg Piddle: ... that's 'im, at the party, warblin' away.
Booyahg Piddle: I had a good chinwag with him though. Interestin' bloke.

Booyahg Piddle: Bloody hell - an' people say goblins are savage.

Crimson: You - you freed me from hunger's lust.
Crimson: Forgive me. I was close to killing you - killing everyone. I am ashamed.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.
The Warden: Is that so? If you are above the General's chief advisor, you must be most impressive.
: True
Narrator: *Her smirk hides her intent - she's toying with you.*
Player: I'm Ketheric's new favourite.
: False
The Warden: Hm. Fascinating.
The Warden: I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.

The Warden: Pockets running a little empty, are they?
The Warden: Disciple Balthazar's orders still stand - none may speak to the prisoners. You can go now.
The Warden: The Absolute thanks you for this generous donation, True Soul. You can go now.
Player: That was so well-played, I'm not even mad.

He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.

He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.

He Who Was: My reasons are of no consequence.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?

Narrator: *Calmness greets you as the submersible slows to a halt. Unlike the Iron Throne, you remain intact.*

Narrator: *Duke Ravengard approaches you, looking confused.*

Duke Ulder Ravengard: My thoughts are my own now, and my purpose certain. I will wait at your camp - we can speak more there.

Lora: I'm so afraid. And so tired. I've been looking night and day, everywhere I could.

Ettvard Needle: Well, well, if it isn't the city's next celebrity! You star in our next edition's top story.

Ettvard Needle: And then we can only hope the Fist do their duty and escort you to the gallows! Your days scumming up this good city's streets will be over.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.

Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?

Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: Don't be dramatic, it's just a bite. One nip and you're done.
Astarion: Easy for you to say, you won't have to taste whatever sludge is in those veins.
Astarion: Fine, I'll do it.

Player: Search for an arcane rune to sabotage.
: True
Narrator: *As the lock opens, a loose page comes with it. Magic pulses from the parchment.*
Narrator: *What was once script is now an obliterated scrawl. You have a sense these are names, a list, but of what?*
Player: Examine the book more closely.
: True
Narrator: *Gods. These are the names of gods, once lost, but now restored after the Second Sundering.*

Fist Marcus: Hello, Isobel.
InternalNodeContext: Marcus never vouched for the players. This is their first encounter with him.
Isobel: Marcus - is that you? What's happened to you?
Fist Marcus: I've been blessed. You can be too. Come with me and you can hear it all from Ketheric himself.
Player: What are you?
Fist Marcus: True Soul. My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Player: Probe his thoughts for more information.
: True
Narrator: *A haunting face swims into your mind's eye, its instructions vivid in your mind: nothing is more important than bringing the girl - alive.*
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: Marcus is trying to kidnap you, Isobel. We're going to need to fight our way out of this one.

Ketheric Thorm: YOU! What have you done?! What have you done to me?!

Ketheric jerkily turns toward the player with hatred in his eyes.
InternalNodeContext: INTRO: Before initial fight
Ketheric Thorm: YOU! What have you done?! What have you done to me?!

Tremors shake the tower now and then, evidence of Nightsong's assault.
Ketheric jerkily turns toward the player with hatred in his eyes.
InternalNodeContext: INTRO: Before initial fight
Ketheric Thorm: You desecrate my halls. Kill my faithful. What heresy twists inside you?!
Player: Surrender now, and I'll consider letting you live.
: True

Player: I may or I may not. But if you try to attack me, I will crush your skull.
: True
Ketheric Thorm: We're not so different, it seems. We both want what we want, and no opposition, no resistance will prevent us.
Ketheric Thorm: And yet... you have beaten me.
Ketheric Thorm: It has taken a century of misfortune. A century of loss. A century of regret.
Ketheric Thorm: And now... perhaps it is over.
Player: Come quietly, and you'll be spared.
Player: It isn't too late, Ketheric. Your story doesn't end here.
Nightsong: KETHERIC THORM!
Nightsong: KETHERIC THORM!
Ketheric Thorm: Aylin.
Nightsong: Rise, you dog! Retribution has come, and her sword is my sword!
Player: Wait - Ketheric has surrendered.

Narrator: *The device is strange, made of taut flesh and pockmarked metal. It waits for something.*
Lae'zel: The zaith'isk. Vlaakith's purity, distilled. My duty. My right.
Player: Go ahead, Lae'zel. You've earned it.
Lae'zel: Praise Vlaakith, let it be done.
Ghustil Stornugoss: Sit, child. Let the zaith'isk end your suffering.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The 'head' part of the machine descends and the jaws clamp around the Laezel's head, neck, shoulders.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

NodeContext: Instructive - this is very important
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A psychic forcefield emerges, 'locking in' Lae'zel's head to the Zaith'isk.

: True

Lae'zel: My Queen, hear me!
Shadowheart: That thing's killing her!
